segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 56
segments.en: Linked Discourses 56

segments.pli: 4. Sīsapāvanavagga
segments.en: 4. In a Rosewood Forest

segments.pli: 39. Indakhīlasutta
segments.en: 39. A Boundary Pillar

segments.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti … pe …
segments.en: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, te aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā mukhaṃ ullokenti:
segments.en: They gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ nūna bhavaṃ jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passatī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, tūlapicu vā kappāsapicu vā lahuko vātūpādāno same bhūmibhāge nikkhitto.
segments.en: Suppose there was a light tuft of cotton-wool or kapok which was taken up by the wind and landed on level ground.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ puratthimo vāto pacchimena saṃhareyya, pacchimo vāto puratthimena saṃhareyya, uttaro vāto dakkhiṇena saṃhareyya, dakkhiṇo vāto uttarena saṃhareyya.
segments.en: The east wind wafts it west; the west wind wafts it east; the north wind wafts it south; and the south wind wafts it north.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Lahukattā, bhikkhave, kappāsapicuno.
segments.en: It’s because the tuft of cotton-wool is so light.

segments.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti … pe …
segments.en: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, te aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā mukhaṃ ullokenti:
segments.en: They gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ nūna bhavaṃ jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passatī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Adiṭṭhattā, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ.
segments.en: It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.

segments.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti … pe …
segments.en: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, te na aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā mukhaṃ ullokenti:
segments.en: They don’t gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ nūna bhavaṃ jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passatī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ayokhīlo vā indakhīlo vā gambhīranemo sunikhāto acalo asampakampī.
segments.en: Suppose there was an iron pillar or a boundary pillar with deep foundations, firmly embedded, imperturbable and unshakable.

segments.pli: Puratthimāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi, neva saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampacāleyya; pacchimāya cepi disāya … pe … uttarāya cepi disāya … pe … dakkhiṇāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi, neva saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampacāleyya.
segments.en: Even if violent storms were to blow up out of the east, the west, the north, and the south, they couldn’t make it shake or rock or tremble.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Gambhīrattā, bhikkhave, nemassa sunikhātattā indakhīlassa.
segments.en: It’s because that boundary pillar is firmly embedded, with deep foundations.

segments.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye ca kho keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti … pe …
segments.en: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

segments.pli: ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, te na aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā mukhaṃ ullokenti:
segments.en: They don’t gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ nūna bhavaṃ jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passatī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Sudiṭṭhattā, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ.
segments.en: It’s because they have clearly seen the four noble truths.

segments.pli: Katamesaṃ catunnaṃ?
segments.en: What four?

segments.pli: Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa … pe … dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa.
segments.en: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo … pe … ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
segments.en: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

segments.pli: Navamaṃ.

sections.title: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly…

suttaplex.blurb: One who has not seen the four noble truths is as feeble as a tuft of cotton wool, while one who has seen them is like a deep-rooted pillar.
